name: SALMON cipher
short_description:
Cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator called 'SALMON'. It is seeded with a 480-bit key and  a 480-bit nonce. The target technology is a stream cipher. Each call to ::Invoke()  returns a 32bit word. On a desktop workstation, SALMON runs at around 2.58 million  invocations per SECOND. A stream cipher built on this PRNG could encrypt over 600 megabytes per minute.

SALMON is heavily derived from a block cipher called SERPENT. SERPENT was a finalist from  the NIST selection tournaments.
	
SALMON is not just a SERPENT cipher operating in chaining mode. It contains five large, hidden tables organized in the manner of blowfish substitution tables. There is also mild use of a portion of Salsa20/12 called a "quarter round function". The seeding portion relies on SHA-2 (the standard hash function of the NSA.)
